revision_history.draft:
Light unspools its thread.  
The air thickens, a woolen sigh.  
Heat clings to the brick, a fossil of day.  
Insects’ hum dissolves to static.  
The streetlamp’s breath fogs the glass.  
Petrichor stirs—earth exhales its last.  
Shadows stretch, not as limbs but as ink.  
Blotting the edges of what was once clear.  
The world unclenches. A pause. Then—  
the dark arrives, not as a fall,  
but a slow, wet unzipping of light.
revision_history.critique:
**What’s alive:**  
The poem’s sensory shift is vivid—“air thickens, a woolen sigh,” “heat clings to the brick,” “petrichor stirs”—anchoring the transition in tactile and environmental details. The metaphor of shadows as “ink” and the enjambment’s momentum toward darkness align with the form guidance. The line “the

final_poem:
Light unspools its thread.  
The air thickens, a woolen sigh.  
Heat clings to the brick, a fossil of the day’s decay.  
Insects’ hum dissolves to static, a buzz of fading.  
The streetlamp’s breath fogs the glass.  
Petrichor stirs—the earth exhales, a breath of rain.  
Shadows stretch, not as limbs but as ink.  
Blotting the edges of what was once clear, a silent erasure.  
The world unclenches—a pause—then the dark arrives,  
not as a fall, but a slow, wet unzipping of light.
